author:
Shane Covey
scovey@reformer.com @ShaneCovey on Twitter
title: Rebels roll into quarterfinals
text:
TOWNSHEND >> Old MacDonald had a farm, and Owen McDonald has a gift. 
He's explosive. 
The senior midfielder often used a quick burst to get himself some space, took eight shots and tallied twice to help the No. 5 Leland & Gray varsity boys soccer team trump 12th-ranked Randolph, 3-0, in a Division 3 playdown game on Tuesday afternoon. 
"We switched to a 4-4-2 setup at halftime to get Owen more looks," said Rebels coach Chris Barton. "He made a lot of nice runs." 
The hosts took a 1-0 lead to the break and were never really challenged on the day, but Barton didn't feel like his team gave its best effort until the last 15 minutes of the game. 
"We definitely played to their level early on. The last 15 minutes were more like the way we play. I don't know what it was. The kids were certainly nervous," noted the coach. "We played well enough to win. We scored three nice goals." 
McDonald simply took over down the stretch. He turned on the jets to get off three consecutive shots that were denied by Randolph keeper Henry Kidder and then made a beautiful cross. He used his speed during a run along the left side before burying a shot to make it 2-0 with 14:13 left and headed home a corner feed 10 minutes later to cap the scoring. 
Nick Morrow made nine saves to get the shutout, but was never really tested. The biggest threat for Randolph was Nathan Gray â€” a beast of a forward who unloaded four powerful shots from long range in Morrow's direction. Advertisement 
"Come on white, where's the intensity?" shouted the Leland & Gray keeper during the first half. 
"Pick it up!" screamed coach Barton. 
The first half was difficult for the large home crowd to watch, aside from pretty passes by Patrick McDonald and Bryce Karg, scoring chances for Cody Cutler and Jullian Plumadore, and Evan Daigneault's rebound goal that gave the hosts a 1-0 lead at the 28:12 mark. 
Leland & Gray's defense was pretty solid, however. With a steady beat coming from drums along the sideline, Patrick McDonald picked Gray's pocket and Jeremy Bovat cleared the ball out of danger a couple of times. 
"Bovat played really well for us in the back. He was probably our player of the game," stated Barton. 
After trying to fire his teammates up during a halftime huddle, Morrow had to make four stops early in the second half to keep the Rebels on top. He denied Gray twice, caught a shot from Liam Connolly and saved one off the foot of Dakota Garrow. 
That's when Owen McDonald began using his gift, as he continually accelerated so that he could get off shots and added a couple of insurance goals. 
The Rebels will host No. 13 Thetford in Friday's quarterfinal at 3 p.m. Thetford upset No. 4 Williamstown, 3-0, on Tuesday.
